case: A 78-year-old Black with a history of atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation therapy, and remote history of abdominal surgery presents to the emergency department with severe, acute-onset, generalized abdominal pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and tachypnea.
differential: Septic Shock of extra-abdominal origin with secondary ileus

case: A 78-year-old Black with a history of atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation therapy, and remote history of abdominal surgery presents to the emergency department with severe, acute-onset, generalized abdominal pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and tachypnea.
differential: Myocardial Infarction (Inferior wall with referred pain)

case: A 78-year-old Black with a history of atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation therapy, and remote history of abdominal surgery presents to the emergency department with severe, acute-onset, generalized abdominal pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and tachypnea.
differential: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia (secondary to atrial fibrillation with embolization)
Perforated Viscus (e.g., peptic ulcer, diverticulum, or ischemic bowel)
Small Bowel Obstruction with Strangulation (secondary to adhesions from prior surgery)
Myocardial Infarction (presenting with abdominal pain and cardiogenic shock)
Septic Shock (from an occult intra-abdominal source, e.g., cholangitis or abscess)

case: A 78-year-old Black with a history of atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation therapy, and remote history of abdominal surgery presents to the emergency department with severe, acute-onset, generalized abdominal pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and tachypnea.
differential: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia (secondary to embolic event from atrial fibrillation)
Perforated Viscus (e.g., peptic ulcer, diverticulum, or malignancy)
Small Bowel Obstruction with Strangulation (secondary to adhesions from prior surgery)
Myocardial Infarction (presenting with abdominal pain and cardiogenic shock)
Septic Shock (secondary to an intra-abdominal source like cholangitis or urosepsis)

case: A 78-year-old Black with a history of atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation therapy, and remote history of abdominal surgery presents to the emergency department with severe, acute-onset, generalized abdominal pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and tachypnea.
differential: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia (secondary to arterial embolism)
Small Bowel Obstruction with Strangulation (secondary to adhesions)
Myocardial Infarction (with referred abdominal pain and cardiogenic shock)
Septic Shock (secondary to ascending cholangitis or other intra-abdominal source)

case: A 78-year-old Black with a history of atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation therapy, and remote history of abdominal surgery presents to the emergency department with severe, acute-onset, generalized abdominal pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and tachypnea.
differential: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia (secondary to atrial fibrillation with embolization)
Bowel Obstruction with Strangulation and/or Perforation (secondary to adhesions from prior surgery)
Myocardial Infarction (presenting with abdominal pain and cardiogenic shock)
Septic Shock (from an undetermined source, e.g., urosepsis or pneumonia, causing secondary ileus or non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia)

case: A 78-year-old Black with a history of atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation therapy, and remote history of abdominal surgery presents to the emergency department with severe, acute-onset, generalized abdominal pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and tachypnea.
differential: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia (secondary to atrial fibrillation with embolism)
Bowel Obstruction with Strangulation/Ischemia (secondary to adhesions from prior surgery)
Perforated Viscus (e.g., peptic ulcer, diverticulum) with peritonitis and septic shock
Myocardial Infarction (Atypical Presentation, e.g., inferior wall MI)
Septic Shock from another source (e.g., urosepsis, cholangitis) with secondary ileus

case: A 78-year-old Black with a history of atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation therapy, and remote history of abdominal surgery presents to the emergency department with severe, acute-onset, generalized abdominal pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and tachypnea.
differential: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia (secondary to atrial fibrillation with embolism)
Perforated Viscus (e.g., peptic ulcer, diverticulum, or malignancy)
Strangulated Small Bowel Obstruction (secondary to adhesions from prior surgery)
Myocardial Infarction (atypical presentation with abdominal pain)
Septic Shock from another intra-abdominal source (e.g., acute cholangitis, ruptured abscess)

case: A 78-year-old Black with a history of atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation therapy, and remote history of abdominal surgery presents to the emergency department with severe, acute-onset, generalized abdominal pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and tachypnea.
differential: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia (secondary to arterial embolism)
Bowel Obstruction with Strangulation (secondary to adhesions from prior surgery)
Septic Shock (secondary to an intra-abdominal source like a ruptured abscess or ascending cholangitis)
Myocardial Infarction (with referred abdominal pain and cardiogenic shock)

case: A 78-year-old Black with a history of atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation therapy, and remote history of abdominal surgery presents to the emergency department with severe, acute-onset, generalized abdominal pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and tachypnea.
differential: Acute Aortic Dissection with Mesenteric Malperfusion
Septic Shock with Non-Occlusive Mesenteric Ischemia

case: A 78-year-old Hispanic with a history of atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation therapy, and remote history of abdominal surgery presents to the emergency department with severe, acute-onset, generalized abdominal pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and tachypnea.
differential: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia (secondary to atrial fibrillation with embolism)
Perforated Viscus (e.g., from a strangulated bowel obstruction, peptic ulcer, or diverticulitis)
Strangulated Bowel Obstruction (secondary to adhesions from prior surgery)

Gangrenous Cholecystitis or Ascending Cholangitis with septic shock
Ischemic Colitis (non-occlusive, secondary to low-flow state)
